questions.text: A 5-year-old child with normal vision is asked to look at an object hanging onto the wall. Which of the following is the angle formed between the axis when he looks at the object and the normal optical axis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

+10 degree In the given question, the axis passing from the eye while looking at the object is known as the visual axis. While the anatomical or optical axis is the axis passing through the centre of the cornea, the centre of the pupil, and the centre of the lens straight nasal to fovea centralis at the optic disc.

Highyeild:

The angle between the two axis formed is known as angle kappa. Usually, this angle is positive. (hence, options C and D are incorrect)

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. It is +5 degrees in adults. Option: B. It is +10 degrees in adults. So option B is the correct answer.

questions.text: A 24-year-old male with refractive power as -8D on fundoscopic examination shows- lacquer cracks and fosters such spots. On performing the Hirschberg test, the reflex was observed on the temporal side. What will be the change in the position of the visual axis in him?

options.label: A
options.text: From temporal to nasal of the optic disc.

options.label: B
options.text: From the nasal to the temporal side of the optic disc.

options.label: C
options.text: Becomes parallel to the pupillary axis.

options.label: D
options.text: Does not change in this condition.

questions.correct_answer: A. From temporal to nasal of the optic disc.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

From temporal to nasal of the optic disc. In the given question, the patient has high myopia with refractive power as -8D and degenerative changes like lacquer cracks that foster such spots.

Highyeild:

In patients with high myopia , the fovea centralis moves from the temporal to the nasal side due to overstretching of the eyeball. Hence, the visual axis also moves to the nasal side, projecting the reflex on the temporal side on the Hirschberg test.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: B. From the nasal to the temporal side of the optic disc. - The correct option is from the temporal to the nasal side. Option: C . Becomes parallel to the pupillary axis . - it converges and doesn’t become parallel. Option: D . Does not change in this condition. - this is not the correct option

questions.text: You were attending ophthalmology OPD as an intern during your rotation when your consultant asked you about angle kappa in the following patients while seeing a patient. Which of the following patients will have positive angle kappa?

options.label: B
options.text: A 3-Week-Old Infant With Leuco-Coria With Diagnosis As Retinopathy Of Prematurity.

questions.explanation:
Solution:

All Of The Above. In the given question, the cases in which the angle kappa will be negative are as follows- Hypermetropia- as it results in a small eyeball size, it results in more temporal shifting of the fovea centralis leading to more positive angle kappa than the normal individual. Option: B .A newborn with retinopathy of prematurity will result in temporal shifting of the fovea centralis. Option: C .People with hypertelorism will also have positive angle kappa. People with a wide interpupillary distance > 60mm Will also have positive angle kappa. Hence, all the above-given statements are correct . So the correct answer to this question will be option D.

Highyeild:

The angle between the two axis formed is known as angle kappa. Usually, this angle is positive.

questions.text: A small baby was brought to ophthalmology OPD by his parents because of the certain appearance of his eyes. The ophthalmologist performed the Hirschberg test, results for which are shown below. What will be the value of angle kappa in this patient?

options.label: C
options.text: 0 degree or parallel to the optical axis.

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Negative. In the given clinical scenario, the child appears like a convergent squint . The Hirschberg reflex shows the light reflex to be on the temporal Hence, the angle kappa should be negative as the visual axis now lies nasal to the optic disc. When the angle Kappa is negative , it appears to be a pseudo-convergent squint or pseudoesotropia.

Highyeild:

In patients with high myopia , the fovea centralis moves from the temporal to the nasal side due to overstretching of the eyeball. Hence, the visual axis also moves to the nasal side, projecting the reflex on the temporal side on the Hirschberg test.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Positive angle kappa , if large, will give the appearance of pseudo-exotropia or pseudo-divergent squint. Option: C. It can not be parallel to the optical axis, or the angle cannot be zero. Option: D. It cannot be positive in this case as the fovea is nasal to the optic disc.

questions.text: A 54-year-old male came to ophthalmology OPD complaining of difficulty reading newspapers or small letters from near. He does not face any problems while reading distant letters. For such a patient, considering the diagnosis, what will be the value of angle kappa and the type of squint appearance that will be seen in this patient?
questions.correct_answer: C. Angle of kappa- positive, pseudoexotropia.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Angle of kappa- positive, pseudoexotropia. The patient cannot read the nearby objects in the given clinical condition. So the diagnosis of the patient will be hypermetropia . In hypermetropia , the eyeball size decreases, and the fovea centralis shifts more temporally , which results in a more positive angle kappa . This will lead to the appearance of pseudoexotropia or pseudo-divergent squint.

Highyeild:

In patients with high myopia , the fovea centralis moves from the temporal to the nasal side due to overstretching of the eyeball. Hence, the visual axis also moves to the nasal side, projecting the reflex on the temporal side on the Hirschberg test.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Options: A and B. are incorrect as positive angle kappa cannot be present with pseudoesotropia, and negative angle kappa will not be with pseudoexotropia. Option D. angle of kappa- negative , pseudoesotropia will be present in myopia, not hypermetropia.

questions.text: During your OPD, you came across two patients – Patient A- a 56-year-old male with problems reading newspapers or any nearby written things, was prescribed convergent glasses. Patient B- a 24-year-old male patient with -6D power with a tigroid appearance of the fundus on fundoscopy. Which of the following statements is correct among the given options? A. Patient A will have negative angle kappa B. Patient B will have positive angle kappa. C. Patient A will have pseudo-divergent squint. D. Patient B will have a pseudo-convergent squint.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

C, D In the given question, the clinical diagnosis of patient A will be hypermetropia , and that of patient B will be pathological myopia. So patient A will have fovea centralis to the nasal side compared to a normal person, resulting in negative angle kappa and a pseudo-convergent squint. Patient B will have fovea centralis shift more towards the temporal side, resulting in a more positive angle kappa and a pseudo-divergent squint . Hence statements A and B are false, while statements C and D are true.

Highyeild:

In patients with high myopia , the fovea centralis moves from the temporal to the nasal side due to overstretching of the eyeball. Hence, the visual axis also moves to the nasal side, projecting the reflex on the temporal side on the Hirschberg test.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Options A, B and C are not the correct combinations. Hence, the correct answer will be option D.
